bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, May 3, 1929

div1.p: Carter writes Russell, on the eve of a trip to Baltimore, about various loose ends she hopes to address with Frost regarding the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, May 3, 1929
div1.opener:
Book, Misel. /Report (weekly)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
AprilMay 3, 1929.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I am glad to be able to write you that I am leaving for
Baltimore early to-morrow morning. Dr. Frost is not yet quite
ready to resume consecutive work on the final revision of Father's
MS, but, in a telephone conversation last night, I learned that
he will have time this week-end to talk over several things which
I feel are of immediate importance (filling in of our long-ready
outline maps etc. etc.). I could then try to get all this work
started so that everything of the sort would be completed by
the time the MS was ready to take to you.

Last night Miss Brown and I made a “re-apportionment” of
material for me to take to Baltimore, I having hoped and expected
to move over “bag and baggage,” including remaining bibliographic
files, MSS and book of reference. However, until Dr. Frost is
actually ready for this material it had better remain with me, as,
although it really is very well worked up, I can think, from time to
time, of some way to simplify a card, or may find one useful for a
cross-reference.

Miss Brown and I also compiled, last night, a very careful
memorandum of things, which it seemed most necessary should be
taken up when I went to Baltimore. I already had a much fuller
Mem., but I think it will be better to keep to immediate essentials
this week-end. For instance, one important thing (very important)
is going to be the title of the book. It has always been called
The History of Yellow Fever, but, [unclear]although the first two introductory
sections, which take us to 1925, the actual historic part of the book
book
-2-
stops, as you know, with the epidemics of 1648 in Yucatan and the
French Antilles for the Americas and with those reported a little
over a hundred years later by Lind and Schotte in Africa. Dr. Frost
It is not then a complete history of yellow fever. This, however, is
not a matter of immediate importance (I wish to the Lord it were!) so
it is not on to-morrow's list. Of course, when Dr. Frost resumes
regular work on the MS (next week I hope) I shall take up everything,
which I have jotted down, as things occurred to me, in my more com-
plete Memorandum.

Miss Brown and I have been very successful in tracing incomplete
references, indeed I've read Las Casas, Oviedo and Herrera until I
actually dream in Spanish! Most of this work, since I last wrote you,
has been done at the Library of Congress as Herrera is in the Rare
Book Room and can only be read there, while the volumes of Oviedo are
so large that it would be very hard to transport them. Of course, were
it necessary for the work I would do so, but I have had a set of Las
Casas at my apartment for night reading: hence something to work on at
both ends of the line. All of these three were well worked up last fall,
but having had this unexpected (and much regretted!) extra time before
to put in onthe bibliography. I think one might almost call them beauti-
fully worked up. For this Miss Brown deserves a lot of the credit.

With very best wishes and I do hope and pray that to-morrow's
trip to Baltimore may indeed prove the actual “beginning of the end!”
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, (Signed) Laura A. Carter. Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division,
The Rookefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
